content.user_title: Transform Ideas into Validated Designs Through Dialogue
content.value_statement: Moving from idea to implementation without proper design leads to rework and missed requirements. This skill guides you through collaborative brainstorming that explores user intent, proposes alternatives, and validates designs incrementally before writing code.
actual_capabilities: Guides iterative design exploration through one question at a time
Proposes multiple approaches with trade-offs and recommendations
Breaks complex designs into 200-300 word sections for validation
Creates timestamped design documents in docs/plans directory
Integrates with git worktrees and implementation planning workflows
Applies YAGNI principles to remove unnecessary complexity
limitations: Does not write implementation code, only design documentation
Requires user interaction for each validation checkpoint
Depends on project context to provide relevant questions
Design quality depends on user responses to clarifying questions

use_cases.title: Feature Planning for Product Managers
use_cases.description: Product managers use this to transform feature requests into technical designs. The skill asks clarifying questions about user needs, constraints, and success criteria before creating detailed specifications that engineering teams can implement.

use_cases.title: Architecture Design for Software Engineers
use_cases.description: Engineers explore different architectural approaches before committing to implementation. The skill proposes alternatives with trade-offs, validates each design section, and creates documentation that serves as implementation reference.

use_cases.title: Requirement Refinement for Technical Leads
use_cases.description: Technical leads refine vague ideas from stakeholders into concrete designs. The collaborative dialogue uncovers hidden requirements, explores edge cases, and documents decisions before team implementation begins.

best_practices: Always run this skill before implementing new features to avoid rework from misunderstood requirements
Answer clarifying questions thoroughly as design quality depends on understanding your constraints and goals
Review each design section carefully before approving to ensure alignment with your vision
anti_patterns: Skipping the brainstorming phase and jumping directly to implementation leads to costly rework
Answering multiple questions at once disrupts the natural flow and may miss important details
Approving design sections without reading them carefully results in misaligned implementations

faq.question: When should I use this skill instead of just describing what I want?
faq.answer: Use this for any creative or architectural work where requirements might be unclear or multiple approaches exist. It prevents building the wrong thing by exploring intent first.

faq.question: How long does the brainstorming process take?
faq.answer: It depends on complexity, but typically 5-10 questions to understand intent, then 3-5 design sections for validation. The time invested prevents much larger rework costs later.

faq.question: Can I skip questions if I already know what I want?
faq.answer: Yes, answer questions quickly if requirements are clear. The skill adapts to your level of certainty and asks fewer questions when direction is obvious.

faq.question: What happens to the design document after creation?
faq.answer: It is saved to docs/plans/ with a timestamp and committed to git. You can reference it during implementation or use it to create detailed implementation plans with other skills.

faq.question: Does this skill write any code?
faq.answer: No, it only creates design documentation. After validating the design, you can use implementation planning skills to generate code or write it yourself following the design.

faq.question: Can I modify the design after it is documented?
faq.answer: Yes, design documents are starting points. You can edit them directly or run the skill again to explore refinements based on new information discovered during implementation.
